title: Fibromyalgia
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: What Is Fibromyalgia?
content: Fibromyalgia is a non-life-threatening, chronic disorder with widespread pain as its main symptom.

This musculoskeletal condition affects your whole body. When you have fibromyalgia, your brain may process pain signals differently. This could cause you to feel more intense pain. You may also have problems with your bowels, memory, sleep, or mood.

A related, key part of fibromyalgia is the presence of " tender points .” These are areas on your muscles and tendons that are tender when pressed. Typically, tender points are in your neck, back, knee , shoulder , elbow , and hip.

You may also have trigger points with fibromyalgia. These are areas on the muscles around your bones that hurt when pressed. Trigger points may also cause pain or tenderness that you feel in other areas of your body. This is called referred pain. You could have weak muscles, too.

A related, key part of fibromyalgia is the presence of " tender points .” These are areas on your muscles and tendons that are tender when pressed. Typically, tender points are in your neck, back, knee , shoulder , elbow , and hip.

You may also have trigger points with fibromyalgia. These are areas on the muscles around your bones that hurt when pressed. Trigger points may also cause pain or tenderness that you feel in other areas of your body. This is called referred pain. You could have weak muscles, too.

sections.heading: Fibromyalgia Symptoms
content: Fibromyalgia symptoms may start after you’ve had a physical injury, surgery, infection, or extreme stress. But you may notice symptoms build up over time for no particular reason.

content_blocks.text: Fibromyalgia symptoms may start after you’ve had a physical injury, surgery, infection, or extreme stress. But you may notice symptoms build up over time for no particular reason.

content: Symptoms may include:
bullets: Muscle pain throughout the body
Tenderness at certain points

Pain that: Ranges from mild discomfort to severe enough to limit daily activities Commonly occurs in the neck, upper back, shoulders, chest, rib cage, lower back, and thighs May feel like a burning, gnawing, throbbing, stabbing, or aching Might come on gradually Could seem worse when you try to relax and is less noticeable during activity
Fatigue
Sleep disturbances
Ill feelings like a persistent flu
Fibro fog, or trouble with mental focus and concentration
Moderate to severe fatigue
Sleep problems, including insomnia
Headaches
Memory lapses
Irritable bowel syndrome ( IBS )
Interstitial cystitis or painful bladder syndrome
Temporomandibular joint ( TMJ ) disorders

content_blocks.text: Symptoms may include:
associated_bullets: Muscle pain throughout the body
Tenderness at certain points

Pain that: Ranges from mild discomfort to severe enough to limit daily activities Commonly occurs in the neck, upper back, shoulders, chest, rib cage, lower back, and thighs May feel like a burning, gnawing, throbbing, stabbing, or aching Might come on gradually Could seem worse when you try to relax and is less noticeable during activity
Fatigue
Sleep disturbances
Ill feelings like a persistent flu
Fibro fog, or trouble with mental focus and concentration
Moderate to severe fatigue
Sleep problems, including insomnia
Headaches
Memory lapses
Irritable bowel syndrome ( IBS )
Interstitial cystitis or painful bladder syndrome
Temporomandibular joint ( TMJ ) disorders

sections.heading: Fibromyalgia Causes
content: The basic cause of fibromyalgia is still unknown. More than one thing may be involved. Possible causes include:
bullets: Problems in the way your brain and nerves process pain. Experts don’t know what causes this. Nerve stimulation may cause you to have high levels of brain chemicals called neurotransmitters. These chemicals lead to changes in how your brain perceives pain. You may feel painful reactions to mild causes.
Not getting enough sleep
Physical or emotional trauma
Infection or other illness

sections.heading: Fibromyalgia Risk Factors
content: Risk factors for fibromyalgia include:
bullets: Sex: Experts estimate that at least 5 million American adults have fibromyalgia. Of these, up to 90% are women.
Family history : Fibromyalgia also seems to run in families so a gene may be at least partly responsible for the condition.
Age: Most people with fibromyalgia begin to notice symptoms between the ages of 20 and 40, but children and older adults may also get the condition.

content_blocks.text: Risk factors for fibromyalgia include:
associated_bullets: Sex: Experts estimate that at least 5 million American adults have fibromyalgia. Of these, up to 90% are women.
Family history : Fibromyalgia also seems to run in families so a gene may be at least partly responsible for the condition.
Age: Most people with fibromyalgia begin to notice symptoms between the ages of 20 and 40, but children and older adults may also get the condition.

sections.heading: Fibromyalgia Diagnosis
content: The doctor will give you a physical exam and ask you about your pain and other symptoms. If you’ve had widespread pain for more than 3 months that has no other clear cause, you may have fibromyalgia.
Other tests may help your doctor diagnose fibromyalgia or rule out other causes of your symptoms:
bullets: Tender point exam, where the doctor presses down on 18 specific areas of your body to see if you feel any pain with a light touch
Complete blood count
Thyroid function test
Blood tests that check for signs of inflammation . These include: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate Cyclic citrullinated peptide test Rheumatoid factor test

sections.heading: Fibromyalgia Treatment
content: Medications , exercise, diet , therapy , and self-management can help relieve your fibromyalgia symptoms.
Medications
Several drugs can relieve fibromyalgia pain , improve sleep, or treat other fibromyalgia symptoms:
Therapy
Different types of therapy can help you cope with fibromyalgia or manage your symptoms:
Lifestyle changes
Changes to your lifestyle may ease fibromyalgia symptoms and help you manage your condition:
bullets: Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen, acetaminophen, and naproxen sodium
Tramadol (Ultram), a prescription pain reliever
Antidepressants like duloxetine (Cymbalta) or milnacipran (Savella) may ease fibromyalgia pain and fatigue
Amitriptyline or cyclobenzaprine, a muscle relaxant, may help you sleep
Gabapentin (Neurontin), an anti- seizure drug, and pregabalin (Lyrica) may ease fibromyalgia symptoms
Physical therapy can help you learn to do exercises such as workouts in a pool, to improve your stamina, strength, and flexibility.
Occupational therapy can help you learn new ways to do tasks at work to put less stress on your body.
Counseling or mental health treatment can help you manage stress and learn to cope with fibromyalgia.
Regular exercise like walking, swimming , biking, or stretching can relieve fibromyalgia pain. Stick with your exercise routines and build up your stamina a little at a time.
Try to get enough sleep at night. Don’t take afternoon naps. Set a regular bedtime and stick to it.

Find ways to manage your stress . Take time to relax. Deep breathing or relaxation exercises may help. Don’t try to do too much in your daily schedule. It’s OK to say no to some invitations or requests.
Eat a healthy diet of fresh foods. Keep your caffeine intake low.

sections.heading: Alternative therapies
content: Some people with fibromyalgia use alternative or complementary treatments to relieve pain or improve their symptoms. These treatments may include:
bullets: Yoga and tai chi ,exercises that include gentle movement and breathing to help you relax
Meditation
Acupuncture , where a trained practitioner inserts tiny needles into the skin at specific spots to ease pain
Massage therapy , which may help ease pain and relieve stress

meta_description: What is fibromyalgia? WebMD gives an overview of this chronic condition.
